DS_Help_Catalog.value: Decisions will have to be made at certain points in the story. The player can select one of the options displayed on-screen. Depending on your choices, your Karma or Affinity to the target character may change.

Karma is a value showing the player’s dispositional tendencies, and changes with your decisions. You can check your current status on the Profile screen in the menu. There are three types of Karma: Harmonious, Wrathful, and Moral. This value changes how the story unfolds.

Affinity is a value showing your intimacy with other characters, and changes with your decisions. You can check your current status on the Profile screen in the menu. Affinity affects the evolution of other characters’ monsters, the frequency of battle backup in combat, and more.

Special destinations for partner monsters of characters with a certain level of Affinity will be added to the Map after specific chapters. Moving to one of these destinations will trigger an evolution event, unlocking a new evolution for that character.
A situation referred to as Free Action can occur during the story. Free Action is basically like Exploration, but has limited moves, and acts mainly to raise Affinity with other characters.

You have a limited number of moves during Free Action. This limit is displayed at the top-right corner of the Map screen (remaining moves/total moves). Free Action ends when you run out of moves. When that happens, you must speak to the character whose Affinity you want to raise.
Moves are consumed by talking with characters, or by triggering certain events. Conversations and events that consume moves have a <sprite index=4> displayed on the map list or focused target.

During Free Action, entering spots on the map with a <sprite index=1> mark will trigger a Free Battle. Battles against Free Monsters (monsters that aren’t main character partner monsters) are opportunities to gain experience and items, and to persuade enemies into becoming allies through conversation. You can take these on as many times as you want, and they are an excellent option for bolstering your battle strength.

During the story, a situation known as Exploration can occur. Choose destinations on the map, then talk to characters or investigate each area. This lets you obtain items and find clues to advance the plot.

Select the Attack command to show the Skill List. Select a skill from the Skill List to use it. You can also check the effect, attribute, range and effect area of any skills in your possession. *This command cannot be used with items in a single turn.

After you choose an attack skill and select a target, the prediction of that attack’s effect is displayed. In addition to basic info such as attribute-related corrections, damage, accuracy and counterattack rate, you can also check supplementary info such as rear attack damage. The higher a target’s counterattack %, the more likely you are to get countered by the enemy after your attack.

All monsters belong to one of three types: Moral, Chaotic, or Harmonious. These have a rock-paper-scissors relationship with each other, boosting attack against weak types and reducing it against strong types.

Units have individual resistances to <sprite index=114> Fire, <sprite index=115> Water, <sprite index=116> Wind, <sprite index=117> Earth, <sprite index=118> Light and <sprite index=119> Dark element skills. The higher the resistance, the less damage they receive from a corresponding skill. Also, equipping certain Enhancement items can boost these resistances.

The direction from which you attack your opponent will affect attack strength. Side attacks are stronger and more accurate than frontal attacks, and rear attacks are stronger and more accurate than side attacks. Also, attacks from the side or rear are not affected by a opponent defending.
Attacks from higher elevations increase the chance of a critical hit. The greater the difference in elevation between the attacker and the target attacked, the greater this chance becomes.

When attacking, you may receive Battle Backup from a friend. The three types of Battle Backup are: Encouragement, Team Attack, and Support. Backup rates change depending on your Affinity with your friends, as well as unit positions on the battle map. The three types of Battle Backup trigger at different rates for each friend.
Encouragement has a set chance to occur before an attack, as a friend cheers on the attacking unit and raises their attack power for that attack only.

Team Attack has a set chance to occur after an attack, and automatically adds an Attack after the attacking unit. This attack does not use the attacker’s turn. Also, Team Attacks only occur when a friend is close to the target of the Team Attack.
Support has a set chance to occur after a unit action. A friend cheers on a unit after their attack, helping them recover a certain amount of HP and SP.

Select the Item command to open a list of Recovery items in your possession. Like skills, each items has its own range and area. Select an item from the list, then select a target to use it. *This command cannot be used with attacks in a single turn.

When Takuma and friends use the Evolve command on a partner unit, an evolution chart will appear. Evolution requires a certain amount of SP, in exchange for dramatically boosting abilities and changing skills. HP also increases dramatically, but the percentage of damage received before Evolution carries over.

Evolved units consume a fixed amount of SP each turn in order to maintain their form, and return to their original (Rookie) form when SP runs out. You can also return them to their original form (devolve them) voluntarily to conserve SP.

Use the Talk command on a main character partner unit to see targets you can talk to. Subjects of conversation are divided into enemies and allies, and you can only talk to enemies in Free Battles or during encounters while exploring.

Talk with allies to receive Encouragement for your unit and gain a variety of effects. The effects of these talks vary by friend, and are shown under the list of conversation subjects. Also, you can only use the Talk command once per friend in battle.

Conversations with enemies progress as you answer questions from a list of options. The answers change suitably for each enemy, and garnering a certain amount of sympathy with your answers will make them hear you out. Also, the outcome of the “Be my friend!” request is determined at a set rate. Monsters of the same type with the highest Karma and same Karma type have higher rates of success (e.g. when Moral Karma is highest, attempts with <sprite index=102> Moral monsters will be more successful).

After you’ve completed your move, or if you just want to move on to the next turn, select the End Turn command to end that unit’s actions. You can pick the direction you want that unit to face when you end their turn.

Units that end a turn without attacking or using items will automatically take a defensive stance. While the unit is defending, any frontal attacks it receives inflict half damage until the next turn. Units automatically stop defending in one turn.

While a unit is in Rookie form (and for all Rookie-level Free Monster units), ending a turn without attacking, using items or talking will recover 10% of their SP. If said unit also does not move, they recover 30% of their SP instead.

Skills are moves unique to each unit, and are classified as <sprite index=105> Physical Attacks (PHYS ATK) or <sprite index=107> Special Attacks (SP ATK). A cursor will appear when you select Move from the Command Menu. Use <sprite index=40>/<sprite index=46> (<sprite index=90>/<sprite index=83>/<sprite index=81>/<sprite index=68>) to select a point in the blue grid (your movement range), then confirm your choice to move. Units with high Movement (<sprite index=112> MOVE AMT) values on their Stats page can move farther. After moving, you can move back to your original position with <sprite index=32> (<sprite index=88>/<sprite index=47>) before you take actions like Attack.

During the story, you can save/load data with <sprite index=35> (<sprite index=67>), check the backlog with <sprite index=34> (<sprite index=86>), use auto-play with <sprite index=99> (<sprite index=81>), and skip playback with <sprite index=97> (<sprite index=68>).

You’re given four options when you lose an Event Battle: Retry, Restart from Map, Load, or Return to Title. Choosing Load or Return to Title lets you return to the Adventure scene prior to the battle. Choosing Restart from Map lets you train in Free Battles before retrying the Event Battle.
